Local Hero: Rita Ridgeon celebrates 40 years at York Theatre Royal

29/06/2013

Jordan Licht interviews the septuagenarian usher, local celebrity, and occasional performer about forging one of the longest careers in the business

Image by

By undefined undefined

When I got the email saying that Rita Ridgeon, a 72-year-old usher at York Theatre Royal, was celebrating 40 years of working at the theatre, my mind wondered and began conjuring up points of comparison to try to digest the full significance of this statement. I thought about how some of the greatest names in the business, like Dame Judi Dench, Ian McKellen and Anthony Hopkins were still the new kids on the block when Rita Ridgeon first took up the theatre mantle. We hear about this sort of thing every day; people are forever breaking records, but it takes an event like this to happen within your own community in order to realise how significant a lifetime achievement like this really is. Considering she has spent her entire career at York theatre Royal, I felt it was fitting to meet with Rita in the theatre itself. The building is an interesting architectural collage, partly mock medieval, with a 1960s concrete structure sprouting from its side, in attempted imitation of the older part. I meet Rita in the 'newer' part of the building. After asking her if she'd like a drink and her insistence that she's 'alright', I ask Rita, petite and with short sprightly reddish hair, if the theatre looked a lot different when she first set foot in the building in 1973. "Well I've only really seen it change once. It was all decorated in green and now it's all in red. As you know, we're going to have a big refit soon, next year, so I've only really seen it change once in decor and stuff." But of course it's not just the decor that's changed. Rita's job has evolved since her first days on the catering team. She told me how when she first came looking for work as a mother of three, the theatre welcomed her with open arms: "Well when I first came here I had small children and I wanted something in the evening - cause you couldn't afford nurseries and things in those days - so my husband could look after them on a night cause he worked in the day...and I came into town one day and I just happened to see this sign saying they need somebody two nights a week... so I just sort of came in and they said 'oh yeah, you can start', so I started! It just sort of built up from there and my kids got bigger and one day...when they left home I was still here!" Nothing in the theatre ever stays static, and Rita's journey is testament to this fact. Starting off in the catering, Rita has learnt the ins and outs of various roles in the theatre. "Well I did work on the catering when I first came here and then I've ushered for a good 20 years now, well I had a period when I wasn't so well so I came to do something easier which was the ushering and I liked it so much that I stayed with it I never went back to the catering. In recent years, as Rita's local celebrity status has grown, she has been known to take the stage on several occasions, especially when called on by the pantomime Legend Berwick Kaler. "Well I've been on stage quite a few times when Berwick's on. He drags me on stage...This year I've been on to do the archery, they had an archery competition on earlier, and I had to pull an arrow on stage so he got me on to do that." Despite her growing celebrity, Rita remains modest and reluctant to be in the limelight: "Yeah, I was saying stop it, stop it, but you can't fight him. He says get up here, get up here, c'mon..." In the last few years, Rita's appearances are progressively becoming essential components of Berwick's pantomimes: "Once he had me on the stage saying I believe in fairies, and I said no I'm not coming on, and he said this show won't go on until you come up here and say it, so I had to go on the stage, and it's always full so you can imagine how I felt...and when I've been here 40 years at Christmas, he did get me on the stage on the last night and said its very nice you've been here 40 years, and gave me a golden Wagon Wheel - I don't know if you've been to the pantos have you?" I shake my head. "Well he gives out Wagon Wheels every night, but if something special goes on he gives you a golden one round your neck and so he gave me one on the last night cause I've been here 40 years." Rita's extraordinary career sets the standard for the rest of the staff as Rita admits: "I started when Frank Marlborough was the headliner, and he was very good, and then Berwick came along, and now he says to me, he's retiring when I do - that's his punch line!" And with her energy and drive, the prospect of retirement seems a mere speck on the horizon. I ask Rita if she can imagine herself here in another ten years. "I don't know, it depends. I mean you never know do you? But I mean I'd like to stay here as long as I can do the job." But what is it that keeps her going? To wake up to the same job for 40 years, I guess there's more to it than the simple necessity of earning a living. "I like meeting people, and chatting. When you work here for a long time you get to know a lot of people that come so you get to chit chat, and its variable, its sociable. And I've met a lot of nice people. You get nice actors as well. And they're all very friendly." But any job dealing with an unpredictable general public must surely present its challenges. "You have problems, like you do with any job don't you? You sometimes get people who sit in the wrong seats and then they get a bit narky with you and they say you've put them there, even though you've told them which is the correct seat. But other than that, no you don't get a lot of problems." So it seems York Theatre Royal visitors are pretty well behaved on the whole. Considering theatre is a notoriously difficult industry to break in to, I lunge at the opportunity to ask for some insider tips and advice. And who better to ask than someone with as good a track record as Rita? Her advice rings clear and simple: "Go for it!" She laughs. "I'd recommend it to anyone. I've had a few people wanting a job and I've brought 'em here. I mean it's a social night, you have to work, but its social. You can watch the show...and then its variable as well... especially with the pantos cause they adlib so much that its different every night. It depends on the show - I'm not big on Shakespeare so sometimes I'll get a bit [she pulls a bored face] if I've watched that for three weeks", she chuckles at the last part. This seems the right moment to ask Rita about her favourite show. When she reveals having seen way over 100 shows, I realise that this is perhaps a harder question to answer than initially anticipated. But Rita barely hesitates: "The Railway Children, did you see that? Yes, I know it wasn't in this theatre but it was our production - And I liked Wind in the Willows, I liked most things we've done I'd say, but I liked ones with a bit of music. We don't do musicals here very often, but we do add music to the shows sometimes. I liked a lot of the plays, and the pantos of course." I ask Rita what she's looking forward to seeing in the upcoming season. She is enthusiastic about the new family show Legend of King Arthur. "I like challenges, even though I've been here a long time. So when we get something like that coming I do like to see it. It's going to be a bit different and it's always nice to look forward to something isn't it?" As our discussion has turned to the future, I ask Rita what she would change in the theatre if she had the run of the place (which she arguable partly has already). After a long pause whilst she smiles reflectively, she replies: "Mmm...I don't know. I wouldn't change my job! I mean yes, the theatre desperately needs decorating, but that's just money ain't it, and it's like an old fashioned building ain't it and I wouldn't like it modernised." We both inspect our open-plan, concrete surroundings, Rita with a touch of sentiment in her eyes. Yes I like it the way it is I suppose, I've been here so long, I'm set in my ways aren't I?! probably somebody younger might come a long and say they'd like different things, but I don't think I would. I'm quite happy with it the way it is"... ...Concrete, pantos and all! And there's no doubting that Rita is as much part of the theatre as the architecture itself. Before I leave, Rita takes me round the auditorium and shows me 'her seat' - It seems fittingly modest for someone who avoids the spotlight - a seat in one of the stalls next to the aisle and far away from the stage, anonymous amidst the rows and rows of identical red seats. As with the Gielgud Theatre and the Harold Pinter Theatre in the West End, named to commemorate these men's major contributions to the stage, as I leave, I imagine that in future years, people will flock to York Theatre Royal to see the Christmas panto in the Rita Ridegon Rooms. But we trust this won't be for many years to come.
